the easiest (safest for your win7) is a WUBI install, goog that 'ubuntu wubi install'
safe because you install within win7. If you decide it works with your hardware, etc. you can dig in deeped, and repartition.
you mean for the sharing of the partitions, right?
kind of. you would create a partition for win7, and some seperate ones for ubuntu. Then there is the whole partition resizing thing...
i read that it will do it for me?
i really don't understand what you're saying
do your homework first! Back up your win7 partition second.
what doing your homework on partitioning, and / or backing up your win7 partition???
you really aren't making sense
do you know how to manipulate partitions on a computer?
ok, then all you need to read up on is what partition requirements ubuntu requires (so much for the homework), next, and before you do any of it, back up your win7 partition. That's it!
I suggested wubi so that you can try it out on your PC. If that goes well, and everything works you should be able to confidently set it up on a dedicated partition.
thanks

the cool thing about a wubi install is that you can get things set up on ubuntu without the pain of partitioning up front. Then back up your config files for use once you decide to partition and reinstall. That, and it lets you jump right in without the potential of destroying your win7 setup.
but as a regular linux user, I don't want the overhead that WUBI creates
I had to assume that you were not a regular linux user up front, for that I am sorry - but it does beg the question "why ask about it in the first place"...
